author: @SaiPraneethMullapudi
text:
ONDC should be developed as a Switch API model like UPI Switch.
But ONDC never had a proper vision and the support/ grevience redressal system in place which is the most important thing for an e-marketplace system to work.

I believe OCEN can be fine tuned.
But credit lending especially the micro credit is something which is always under tight RBI Watch and the time period from 2023-2025 is of high interest rate regimes.
It's more like Policy Bazar for credit.
It can be implemented well. But target lenders should be NBFCs which are currently in partnership with Slice or KreditBee type apps which are bridging the very micro credit gap of 10s of thousands.
Banks will show reluctance as they want Bank account to be opened before processing any loan but NBFCs which are currently lending through apps like Slice, KreditBee etc have no such restrictions while lending. Only credit account and KYC is needed that's it.

Unlike UPI which is a transaction switch and there is a set of guidelines for transaction mechanism set by RBI.
There is no one such mechanism in place for marketplace like model because Marketplace is something which Government cannot control by placing a Standard Operating Procedure as such like a Bank 2 Bank transaction.

But yes OCEN can be made successful but ONDC is very difficult.

author: @SaiPraneethMullapudi
text:
For Salary processing there is NEFT since a long time and it processes a batch of transactions at same time.
NEFT is specifically designed for Bank to Bank transactions.

author: @tejaswi5kadialas
text:
Despite the massive success of UPI‚Äîlargely accelerated by the pandemic pushing India towards digital payments‚Äîit‚Äôs disheartening to see initiatives like ONDC and OCEN failing to strike a chord with the masses. These projects, while ambitious, seem to lack ground-level understanding of Indian consumer behavior. People here don't easily switch platforms once they are comfortable with a vendor. Case in point: Zepto‚Äôs rapid rise has significantly impacted Amazon Fresh, showing how quickly preferences can shift‚Äîbut only when there's real value.

Unfortunately, ONDC and OCEN feel like experiments that have consumed time, money, and energy without practical outcomes. Aadhaar itself may not have gained traction if it wasn‚Äôt made mandatory‚Äîits success is more by enforcement than adoption. Nandan Nilekani‚Äôs vision for a digital India, inspired by systems like the SSN in the U.S., is admirable, but implementation without alignment to public sentiment risks becoming a missed opportunity. These initiatives need more than vision‚Äîthey need relevance, usability, and most importantly, public trust.

One day, suddenly my gpay stopped working. It's been 3 months now, and i dont have any digital payment app. Yes, no other ones as well, because I am assuming some issue with UPI.

And the app didnt work.
So, i have no ther option than to live without these.
Fortunately üòí Im unemployed and dont spend rarely, so it's not affecting me much.
Right now Im using Card payment.
And and and, there is one more thing.
My mobile is an Android 9.
So, no YONO. no Digilocker. etc.

I understand there must be some security purpose for this, but why do i have to change my perfectly fine working mobile to access this all? If someone is unemployed like me, how is he/she supossed to catch up? Why is there no solution for such users?

im wondering how many people are in the same boat.

author: @UjwalRam
text:
India makes bold moves to expand UPI internationally, making a real dent in the domain long ruled by global giants like SWIFT, Visa, and Mastercard, we suddenly see nationwide disruptions. Coincidence? Or pressure from those whose monopoly is now being challenged?

These aren‚Äôt scattered issues. UPI systems across different banks and platforms failing in waves suggests coordinated stress or targeting, not isolated outdated infrastructure. Even during demonetization, COVID lockdowns, or festive transaction peaks, the system never cracked like this.


We need to fortify ourselves to fight with these giants and then try expanding globally. Otherwise they will mess with our internal system as well.

author: @shaktimaan1064
text:
They first captured India‚Äôs data off entire loan market bye capturing share in Cibil Buy transunion. Then we search the internet banking website on Google and enter our credentials, so our entire details are with Google. Dave provided card network services so our card and account details are with American companies like Visa and MasterCard. UPI was symbol of our independence from dependency on American companies. But there also Google sneaked into UPI and our independent payment system again went in their hands. Now these ONDC also will go in hand of Microsoft‚Äôs. So whatever we purchase on e-commerce, will be through Microsoft‚Äôs platform.
It seems this is all deliberate move off American establishment and government as they don‚Äôt want our financial system/currency/payment settlement to go out of the orbit of their dominance and dependence. It‚Äôs very easy for them to bribe the concerned Indian officials/politicians for allowing them to participate in our systems, which can be easily run indigenously. It clearly appears that this is all due to strategic reason. India is very big country with large resources and population. If any time in future if India turns strategically adverse or rival country, they can hijack the entire financial and banking/payment system of India.
Jago Indians Jago when we will be free from digital colonisation. Or at least when we will strive to be independent from digital colonisation.

replies.author: @merehumanobserver
replies.text:
UPI has been an innovation that has been forced upon the Indian citizens, because the launch of UPI was promptly followed by demonetisation.

And demonetisation prompted an urgency among everyday individuals who kept a little cash at hand for emergencies to get in line in banks or risk loosing their money, whereas the rich are still funnelling unaccounted cash which you get to know as and when it is reported.

If it would've been adopted decently without demonetisation, then you could've argued that it is a success.

And well who knows, demonetisation after decent adoption of UPI would've been a lot more seamless than it happened.

replies.author: @Mr.Hoffmannn
replies.text: Only because it was free for consumers and sellers. No transaction charges. Even he said in this video that government FORCED giants banks to not charge any transaction fees. Do you really think that countries like USA, UK, China, and other tech-rich countries would not have launched their version of UPI way before if they had been able to convince their banks for no transaction fees? You are looking at UPI as a consumer, but think if you are the owner of the bank and you provide your customer the service of online transaction by developing the tech, hiring employees, paying different charges, salaries, development and maintenance cost, charges of api calling per transaction, running the app and etc, and all of these expenses CAN BE covered by charging 1 or 2% of each transaction fees(like 1 or 2 rupees on 100rs payment) but your government tell you that you can not charge anything, and give it all for free. What would you have done?
